ground_truth: The officer commanding and the Guard of Honor await him. The young Englishman glances at him quizzically. The General has taken the salute and moves to inspect the troops to the accompaniment of the military band. He is suddenly aware of a well-dressed Indian half-listening to their conversation. He glances at him and the well-dressed Indian simply nods slightly and moves off a little. The second Englishman grimaces at the young Englishman and looks down again. Another far less elaborate gangplank extends from the aft section of the ship. Third Class passengers are disembarking here, and on shore, separated by a wire fence from the rest of the pier. A large crowd of Indians is reacting excitedly to someone coming down the gangplank but we can't yet see that person. The young Englishman glances back cautiously toward the well-dressed Indian again, then. Gandhi is smiling, trying to move on, but answering the questions of an Indian journalist. He speaks with an uncertainty and tentativeness that he had lost in South Africa, patently overwhelmed by the reception. An English journalist catches him as he turns. An exuberant woman puts a garland over his shoulders. An Indian reporter has cornered Ba behind him. She joins her hands, acknowledging a garland placed around her shoulders, and pushes on after Gandhi. Charlie helps to guide her. The young Nehru, somewhat amused by all the excitement, leads Gandhi through the crowd to a little flower-covered platform. We see a banner: THE CONGRESS PARTY. He grins. He has guided Gandhi to the first step of the platform. Another garland is wrapped around Gandhi's shoulders, and in some embarrassment, he mounts the platform. There is a great cheer, but in the silence that follows we hear the military band from across the way as the troops prepare to march off. Gandhi looks around at the crowd. Finally he speaks out. He makes the pranam and starts for the steps. The crowd is a little disappointed, but they manage a cheer and applause. Nehru is standing next to a heavy-set, well-dressed man (Patel). Nehru has slammed the door of a gleaming Rolls Royce touring car, the top down. He has seated Gandhi in it beside Patel, taking Gandhi's knapsack. An Indian chauffeur rides in front. The crowd still surges around and Gandhi is looking apprehensively back for Ba. He grins boyishly, in part to comfort, in part unable to contain his amusement at Gandhi and his evident confusion. With Gandhi still looking back anxiously, the car pulls off. He finally turns to Patel. There are crowds along the street, and Gandhi -- in surprise that they are for him -- waves tentatively. Patel waves too but he eyes Gandhi rather critically.

test_cases.name: Synonym Substitution

The General has taken the salute and proceeds to inspect the troops to the accompaniment of the military ensemble. He is suddenly conscious of a well-dressed Indian half-listening to their dialogue. He has guided Gandhi to the first step of the platform. Another garland is wrapped around Gandhi's shoulders, and in some embarrassment, he mounts the platform. There is a great cheer, but in the silence that follows we hear the military ensemble from across the way as the troops prepare to march off. Gandhi looks around at the crowd. Finally he speaks out. He makes the pranam and starts for the steps. The crowd is a little disappointed, but they manage a cheer and applause. Nehru is standing next to a heavy-set, well-dressed man (Patel). test_cases.name: Active <-> Passive Transformation
test_cases.description: The officer commanding and the Guard of Honor are awaited by him. A quizzical glance is given to him by the young Englishman. The salute has been taken by the General and the troops are inspected by him to the accompaniment of the military band. A well-dressed Indian is suddenly aware of their conversation being half-listened to by him. He is glanced at by the well-dressed Indian, who simply nods slightly and moves off a little. The young Englishman is grimaced at by the second Englishman, who looks down again. Another far less elaborate gangplank is extended from the aft section of the ship. Third Class passengers disembark here, and on shore, a large crowd of Indians reacts excitedly to someone coming down the gangplank, but that person can't yet be seen by us. The well-dressed Indian is glanced back at cautiously by the young Englishman, then. Gandhi is smiling, trying to move on, but the questions of an Indian journalist are answered by him. He speaks with uncertainty and tentativeness, lost by him in South Africa, patently overwhelmed by the reception. He is caught by an English journalist as he turns. His shoulders are garlanded by an exuberant woman. Ba, behind him, has been cornered by an Indian reporter. Her hands are joined by her, acknowledging a garland placed around her shoulders, and after Gandhi, she pushes on. She is guided by Charlie. Gandhi is led through the crowd to a little flower-covered platform by the young Nehru, somewhat amused by all the excitement. A banner is seen by us: THE CONGRESS PARTY. A grin is given by him. Gandhi has been guided by him to the first step of the platform. Another garland is wrapped around Gandhi's shoulders, and in some embarrassment, the platform is mounted by him. A great cheer is heard, but in the silence that follows, the military band is heard from across the way as the troops prepare to march off. The crowd is looked around at by Gandhi. Finally, he speaks out. The pranam is made by him and the steps are started for. A little disappointment is felt by the crowd, but a cheer and applause are managed by them. Nehru is standing next to a heavy-set, well-dressed man (Patel). The door of a gleaming Rolls Royce touring car has been slammed by Nehru, the top down. Gandhi has been seated by him in it beside Patel, and his knapsack is taken by Nehru. The car is ridden in front by an Indian chauffeur. The crowd still surges around and Ba is looked back for apprehensively by Gandhi. He grins boyishly, in part to comfort, in part unable to contain his amusement at Gandhi and his evident confusion. With Gandhi still looking back anxiously, the car is pulled off. Patel is finally turned to by him. There are crowds along the street, and Gandhi -- in surprise that they are for him -- waves tentatively. Patel waves too but Gandhi is eyed rather critically by him.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L1
test_cases.description: The commanding officer and the Guard of Honor await him. A young Englishman looks at him quizzically. The General takes the salute and inspects the troops as the military band plays. He notices a well-dressed Indian half-listening to their conversation, who nods slightly and moves away. Another Englishman grimaces at the young Englishman. A simpler gangplank extends from the ship's aft section for Third Class passengers, separated by a wire fence onshore. A large crowd of Indians reacts excitedly to someone disembarking, but the person is not yet visible. The young Englishman glances back at the well-dressed Indian. Gandhi, smiling and overwhelmed by the reception, answers an Indian journalist's questions. An English journalist approaches him, and an exuberant woman places a garland over his shoulders. An Indian reporter corners Ba, who acknowledges a garland and follows Gandhi, guided by Charlie. A young Nehru, amused by the excitement, leads Gandhi through the crowd to a flower-covered platform with a banner: THE CONGRESS PARTY. Gandhi, embarrassed, mounts the platform as another garland is placed on him. A cheer erupts, followed by silence as the military band plays and troops prepare to march off. Gandhi addresses the crowd, makes the pranam, and heads for the steps. The crowd, slightly disappointed, cheers and applauds. Nehru stands next to Patel, a heavy-set man, and closes the door of a Rolls Royce with Gandhi seated beside Patel. An Indian chauffeur drives, and the crowd surges around. Gandhi looks back for Ba, grinning to comfort and amused by his confusion. As the car departs, he turns to Patel. Crowds line the street, and Gandhi, surprised they are for him, waves tentatively. Patel waves too, eyeing Gandhi critically.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L2
test_cases.description: The commanding officer and Guard of Honor await him. A young Englishman glances quizzically. The General takes the salute, inspects troops with a military band. A well-dressed Indian half-listens, nods, and moves away. Another Englishman grimaces. A simpler gangplank disembarks Third Class passengers, separated by a fence. Excited Indians react to someone unseen. The young Englishman glances at the Indian again. Gandhi smiles, overwhelmed by the reception, answers an Indian journalist. An English journalist catches him. A woman garlands him. An Indian reporter corners Ba, who acknowledges a garland and follows Gandhi. Charlie guides her. Nehru, amused, leads Gandhi to a flower-covered platform with a CONGRESS PARTY banner. Gandhi mounts the platform, embarrassed, amid cheers. Silence follows as the military band plays. Gandhi speaks, makes pranam, and starts for the steps. The crowd cheers. Nehru stands with Patel, slams a Rolls Royce door, seats Gandhi beside Patel, and takes his knapsack. An Indian chauffeur drives. Gandhi looks for Ba, grins boyishly, and the car departs. He waves at crowds, surprised they are for him. Patel waves, eyeing Gandhi critically.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L1
test_cases.description:
The officer in command, along with the Guard of Honor, stands ready and waiting for his arrival. The young Englishman, with a curious expression, glances at him, trying to make sense of the situation. The General, having taken the salute with due formality, proceeds to inspect the assembled troops, all to the stirring accompaniment of the military band playing nearby. In the midst of this, he suddenly becomes aware of a well-dressed Indian gentleman who seems to be half-listening to their ongoing conversation. The General glances at this well-dressed Indian, who simply nods slightly in acknowledgment and then moves off a little distance away. Meanwhile, the second Englishman grimaces at the young Englishman, then lowers his gaze once more. 

In another part of the scene, a far less elaborate gangplank extends from the aft section of the ship. Here, Third Class passengers are in the process of disembarking, and on the shore, they are separated by a wire fence from the rest of the bustling pier. A large crowd of Indians is reacting with excitement to someone making their way down the gangplank, though the identity of this person remains unseen for the moment. The young Englishman, feeling a sense of caution, glances back once more toward the well-dressed Indian. 

At this point, Gandhi is seen smiling, attempting to move forward while simultaneously answering the questions posed by an Indian journalist. He speaks with a noticeable uncertainty and tentativeness, a demeanor he had shed during his time in South Africa, now clearly overwhelmed by the enthusiastic reception. An English journalist manages to catch him as he turns. An exuberant woman steps forward and places a garland over his shoulders. Meanwhile, an Indian reporter has cornered Ba, who is just behind him. She joins her hands in a gesture of acknowledgment as another garland is placed around her shoulders, and she continues to push on after Gandhi, with Charlie assisting to guide her. 

The young Nehru, somewhat amused by the entire scene and all the excitement surrounding it, leads Gandhi through the thronging crowd to a small platform adorned with flowers. A banner prominently displays the words: THE CONGRESS PARTY. Nehru grins as he guides Gandhi to the first step of the platform. Another garland is wrapped around Gandhi's shoulders, and with some embarrassment, he ascends the platform. A great cheer erupts from the crowd, but in the silence that follows, the sound of the military band can be heard from across the way as the troops prepare to march off. Gandhi takes a moment to look around at the gathered crowd. Finally, he speaks out, making the pranam gesture before starting for the steps. The crowd, though a little disappointed, manages to muster a cheer and applause. 

Nehru stands next to a heavy-set, well-dressed man, known as Patel. Nehru has just slammed the door of a gleaming Rolls Royce touring car, its top down, and has seated Gandhi inside it beside Patel, taking care of Gandhi's knapsack. An Indian chauffeur is seated in the front. The crowd continues to surge around them, and Gandhi looks back apprehensively, searching for Ba. He grins boyishly, partly to offer comfort and partly because he cannot contain his amusement at the situation and his evident confusion. With Gandhi still looking back anxiously, the car finally pulls away. He eventually turns to Patel. As they drive along the street, they encounter more crowds, and Gandhi, surprised that they are there for him, waves tentatively. Patel also waves, but he casts a rather critical eye on Gandhi.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L2
test_cases.description:
The officer in command, accompanied by the distinguished Guard of Honor, stands poised and prepared, waiting in anticipation for his arrival. Observing this, the young Englishman, wearing a look of curiosity on his face, glances at the officer, attempting to piece together and make sense of the unfolding situation. The General, having received the salute with the appropriate level of formality, moves forward to conduct a thorough inspection of the assembled troops. This action is set to the stirring and rousing music provided by the military band, playing energetically nearby. During this moment, he suddenly becomes conscious of the presence of a well-dressed Indian gentleman, who appears to be half-engaged and half-listening to the ongoing conversation. The General casts a glance toward this well-dressed Indian, who acknowledges the glance with a subtle nod before moving off a short distance away. Meanwhile, the second Englishman grimaces slightly at the young Englishman, and then, lowering his gaze, looks away once more.

Elsewhere in the scene, there is a far less elaborate gangplank extending from the aft section of the ship, contrasting with the formality seen earlier. Here, Third Class passengers are in the process of carefully disembarking, and on the shore, they find themselves separated from the rest of the bustling pier by a wire fence. A large crowd of Indians, filled with excitement and anticipation, reacts with enthusiasm to someone making their way down the gangplank. However, the identity of this person remains obscured for the moment. The young Englishman, feeling a sense of caution and curiosity, glances back once more in the direction of the well-dressed Indian.

At this moment, Gandhi appears on the scene, smiling warmly, as he tries to make his way forward while simultaneously responding to questions posed by an Indian journalist. He speaks with noticeable uncertainty and tentativeness, a demeanor that had been discarded during his time in South Africa, but now seems overwhelmed by the enthusiastic reception he is receiving. An English journalist manages to catch him just as he turns. An exuberant woman steps forward, grinning, and gently places a garland over his shoulders. Meanwhile, an Indian reporter has cornered Ba, who is just behind Gandhi. Ba joins her hands together in a gesture of acknowledgment as another garland is carefully placed around her shoulders, and she continues to follow Gandhi, with Charlie providing assistance and guidance to help her navigate through the crowd.

The young Nehru, finding amusement in the entire scene and all the excitement surrounding it, leads Gandhi through the thronging, bustling crowd toward a small platform that is beautifully adorned with flowers. A banner prominently displays the words: THE CONGRESS PARTY. Nehru, with a grin on his face, guides Gandhi to the first step of the platform. Another garland is wrapped around Gandhi's shoulders, and with an expression of slight embarrassment, he ascends the platform. A great cheer erupts from the crowd, but as the cheers subside, the sound of the military band can be heard once more from across the way, as the troops prepare to march off in an orderly fashion. Gandhi takes a brief moment to look around at the gathered crowd before he speaks out, making the pranam gesture with his hands before he begins to move toward the steps. The crowd, though a little disappointed by his departure, manages to muster a cheer and applause.

Nehru stands next to a heavy-set, well-dressed man, known as Patel. Nehru has just firmly closed the door of a gleaming Rolls Royce touring car, its top stylishly down, and has seated Gandhi inside it beside Patel, taking careful care of Gandhi's knapsack. An Indian chauffeur is seated in the front, ready to drive. The crowd continues to surge energetically around them, and Gandhi looks back with a hint of apprehension, searching intently for Ba. He grins boyishly, offering comfort and reassurance, unable to contain his amusement at the situation and his evident confusion. With Gandhi still looking back anxiously, the car finally begins to pull away. He eventually turns his attention to Patel. As they drive along the street, encountering more crowds, Gandhi is taken by surprise that they are gathered for him, prompting him to wave tentatively. Patel, too, waves, but he casts a rather critical and discerning eye on Gandhi as they proceed.

test_cases.name: Macro-Actions -> Micro-Actions
test_cases.description: The officer commanding stands at attention alongside the Guard of Honor, both waiting expectantly for his arrival. The young Englishman, standing nearby, casts a quizzical glance in his direction, trying to make sense of the situation. As the General arrives, he formally takes the salute, acknowledging the respect shown to him, and then proceeds to move with deliberate steps to inspect the troops, all while the military band plays a stirring accompaniment. In the midst of this formal inspection, he suddenly becomes aware of a well-dressed Indian who seems to be only half-engaged in their conversation, his attention divided. The General glances at this Indian, who responds with a slight nod of acknowledgment before discreetly moving a little distance away. Meanwhile, the second Englishman, observing the scene, grimaces at the young Englishman, then lowers his gaze, perhaps in contemplation or disapproval. At the aft section of the ship, another gangplank, far less elaborate than the first, is extended, allowing Third Class passengers to disembark. These passengers, upon reaching the shore, find themselves separated from the rest of the pier by a wire fence. A large crowd of Indians, gathered on the shore, reacts with excitement to someone descending the gangplank, though the identity of this person remains obscured for the moment. The young Englishman, feeling a sense of caution, glances back toward the well-dressed Indian once more. Meanwhile, Gandhi, with a smile on his face, attempts to move forward, yet finds himself answering the questions posed by an Indian journalist. His speech carries an uncertainty and tentativeness, a stark contrast to the confidence he had gained in South Africa, as he is visibly overwhelmed by the enthusiastic reception. An English journalist seizes the moment to catch Gandhi's attention as he turns, while an exuberant woman steps forward to place a garland over his shoulders. Behind him, an Indian reporter has managed to corner Ba, who joins her hands in a gesture of acknowledgment as another garland is placed around her shoulders, before she continues to follow Gandhi, with Charlie assisting her in navigating through the crowd. The young Nehru, finding amusement in the excitement surrounding them, takes the lead in guiding Gandhi through the throng to a small platform adorned with flowers. As they approach, a banner comes into view, proclaiming: THE CONGRESS PARTY. Nehru grins, having successfully led Gandhi to the first step of the platform. Another garland is draped around Gandhi's shoulders, and with a touch of embarrassment, he ascends the platform. A great cheer erupts from the crowd, but as silence descends, the sound of the military band from across the way becomes audible, signaling the troops' preparation to march off. Gandhi takes a moment to look around at the gathered crowd before finally speaking out. He performs the pranam, a gesture of respect, and begins to make his way toward the steps. The crowd, though a bit disappointed by his departure, manages to muster a cheer and applause. Nehru stands beside a heavy-set, well-dressed man, identified as Patel, and with a decisive motion, he slams the door of a gleaming Rolls Royce touring car, its top down, having seated Gandhi inside next to Patel and taken charge of Gandhi's knapsack. An Indian chauffeur sits at the front, ready to drive. As the car begins to move, the crowd continues to surge around them, and Gandhi, looking back with concern, searches for Ba. He grins boyishly, partly to offer comfort and partly because he cannot suppress his amusement at the situation and Gandhi's evident confusion. With Gandhi still casting anxious glances backward, the car pulls away, and he eventually turns his attention to Patel. As they drive along the street, they encounter more crowds, and Gandhi, surprised to realize that the cheers are for him, waves tentatively. Patel also waves, though he casts a critical eye on Gandhi, assessing the scene with a discerning gaze.

test_cases.name: Micro-Actions -> Macro-Actions
test_cases.description: The officer commanding and the Guard of Honor await the General, who takes the salute and inspects the troops as the military band plays. A young Englishman observes the scene, while a well-dressed Indian listens in on their conversation, nods, and steps away. Meanwhile, third-class passengers disembark from a simpler gangplank, greeted by an excited crowd of Indians reacting to an unseen figure. The young Englishman glances back at the well-dressed Indian, then notices Gandhi, who is smiling and engaging with an Indian journalist, overwhelmed by the reception. An English journalist approaches Gandhi, and an exuberant woman places a garland over his shoulders. Nearby, Ba is cornered by an Indian reporter, acknowledges a garland, and moves on with Charlie's help. Young Nehru, amused by the excitement, guides Gandhi through the crowd to a flower-covered platform marked by a "THE CONGRESS PARTY" banner. Gandhi, embarrassed by another garland, steps onto the platform to cheers, but the crowd falls silent as the military band plays across the way. Gandhi addresses the crowd, makes the pranam, and heads for the steps, prompting a cheer and applause despite some disappointment. Nehru, standing with Patel, seats Gandhi in a Rolls Royce beside Patel, taking his knapsack, while an Indian chauffeur drives. As the car departs, Gandhi looks back for Ba, grinning boyishly at the situation. The car moves through streets lined with cheering crowds, and Gandhi, surprised by the attention, waves tentatively, while Patel critically observes him.

test_cases.name: Insert Attributes, Emotions and Scene
test_cases.description:
The officer commanding, responsible for maintaining military protocol, and the Guard of Honor, a ceremonial unit recognizing dignitaries, await him. The young Englishman, likely a colonial official, glances at him quizzically. The General has taken the salute, a customary military greeting, and moves to inspect the troops to the accompaniment of the military band, which plays martial music to inspire pride and discipline. He is suddenly aware of a well-dressed Indian, possibly an influential local figure or a political leader, half-listening to their conversation. He glances at him and the well-dressed Indian simply nods slightly and moves off a little. 

The second Englishman grimaces at the young Englishman, sharing in the tension of the moment, and looks down again. Another far less elaborate gangplank, likely used by lower-class passengers, extends from the aft section of the ship. Third Class passengers, those who traveled in basic accommodations, are disembarking here, and on shore, separated by a wire fence from the rest of the pier. A large crowd of Indians, likely supporters or onlookers, is reacting excitedly to someone coming down the gangplank, but we can't yet see that person. 

The young Englishman glances back cautiously toward the well-dressed Indian again, then. Gandhi, recently returned to India after years spent advocating for civil rights in South Africa, is smiling, trying to move on, but answering the questions of an Indian journalist eager for his views on his future actions. He speaks with an uncertainty and tentativeness that he had lost in South Africa, patently overwhelmed by the reception. An English journalist, part of the press contingent covering this significant event, catches him as he turns. An exuberant woman, likely an admirer, puts a garland over his shoulders, a traditional gesture of respect and welcome. An Indian reporter, keen to capture every detail, has cornered Ba behind him. She joins her hands, acknowledging a garland placed around her shoulders, and pushes on after Gandhi. Charlie, a likely aide or assistant, helps to guide her. The young Nehru, a future leader of India and then a rising political figure, somewhat amused by all the excitement, leads Gandhi through the crowd to a little flower-covered platform. We see a banner: THE CONGRESS PARTY, the leading organization in India's independence movement. He grins. He has guided Gandhi to the first step of the platform. Another garland is wrapped around Gandhi's shoulders, and in some embarrassment, he mounts the platform. There is a great cheer, but in the silence that follows we hear the military band from across the way as the troops prepare to march off. Gandhi looks around at the crowd, assessing the depth of public support. Finally he speaks out. He makes the pranam, a traditional Indian gesture of respect, and starts for the steps. The crowd is a little disappointed, hoping for more, but they manage a cheer and applause. 

Nehru is standing next to a heavy-set, well-dressed man, Patel, another key figure in the Indian independence movement. Nehru has slammed the door of a gleaming Rolls Royce touring car, the top down, a symbol of status and modernity. He has seated Gandhi in it beside Patel, taking Gandhi's knapsack, an emblem of his simplicity and ascetic lifestyle. An Indian chauffeur, indicating the elite status of the passengers, rides in front. The crowd still surges around and Gandhi is looking apprehensively back for Ba, his wife and steadfast partner. He grins boyishly, in part to comfort, in part unable to contain his amusement at Gandhi and his evident confusion. With Gandhi still looking back anxiously, the car pulls off. He finally turns to Patel, aware of the discussions and decisions that await them. There are crowds along the street, and Gandhi -- in surprise that they are for him, reflective of his modesty -- waves tentatively. Patel waves too but he eyes Gandhi rather critically, considering the challenging path ahead for India's independence movement.

The General has taken the salute and moves to inspect the troops to the accompaniment of the military band. He is suddenly aware of a welldressed Indian halflistening to their conversation. He glances at him and the welldressed Indian simply nods slightly and moves off a little. The second Englishman grimaces at the young Englishman and looks down again. Another far less elaborate gangplank extends from the aft section of the ship. Third Class passengers are disembarking here and on shore separated by a wire fence from the rest of the pier. The young Englishman glances back cautiously toward the welldressed Indian again. then Gandhi is smiling trying to move on but answering the questions of an Indian journalist. In the neonlit back alleys of a dystopian metropolis a rogue hacker races against time while being chased by relentless cyborg enforcers their footsteps echoing off rainsoaked pavement. Under the relentless desert sun a lone gunslinger confronts a notorious outlaw at a deserted crossroads both men exchanging steely glances as swirling dust blurs the horizon. On a foggy evening in Victorian London an intrepid detective uncovers a hidden conspiracy among the city’s elite with gaslit streets setting the stage for a race against a mounting darkness. High above a sprawling city skyline a daredevil pilot executes deathdefying maneuvers in a vintage biplane narrowly evading enemy fire as the ground morphs into a dizzying mosaic below. Within the creaking walls of an old countryside manor an estranged family gathers for a mysterious inheritance their hushed whispers and secret glances weaving a tapestry of betrayal and suspense. Amidst the roaring tempest of a stormy ocean a weathered sailor battles nature’s fury on a creaking vessel his resolve as steadfast as the crashing waves that threaten to engulf him. On a bustling 1960s New York street a passionate artist finds unexpected inspiration in the chaotic interplay of urban life capturing moments of love loss and defiant hope on a rainsoaked canvas. Deep in the heart of an enchanted forest a brave knight embarks on a perilous quest to rescue a captive princess facing mythical creatures and treacherous traps with unwavering courage. During a heated political rally in a futuristic city a charismatic leader stokes both hope and dissent. as holographic banners illuminate the night sky and fervent crowds surge with anticipation. In the eerie silence of a postapocalyptic wasteland a hardened survivor scavenges through abandoned ruins haunted by the echoes of a oncethriving civilization now reduced to dust. Beneath the shimmering surface of an underwater kingdom a rebellious mermaid defies ancient traditions to explore forbidden coral reefs and secret caverns brimming with forgotten lore. In the quiet confines of a suburban attic an unassuming teenager stumbles upon a mysterious portal that thrusts him into a surreal world where the very fabric of time and space unravels. On the rugged highlands of Scotland a stoic warrior faces rival clans and ancient curses alike his fierce battle cry resonating across mistcovered moors and turbulent skies. Amid the vibrant chaos of a South American carnival a fearless dancer twirls through streets bursting with color and rhythm each graceful move challenging the rigid boundaries of tradition. During a clandestine meeting in a snowcovered mountain lodge two rival spies exchange cryptic messages hinting at an imminent global conspiracy. their whispered words carried off by the howling wind. Inside a lavish 1920s speakeasy a troubled jazz musician pours his soul into a melancholic melody every note echoing the bittersweet memories of lost love and shattered dreams. In a futuristic space station orbiting a distant planet an intrepid crew confronts bizarre alien phenomena and an enigmatic interstellar threat pushing the limits of human endurance. Another garland is wrapped around Gandhi's shoulders and in some embarrassment he mounts the platform. There is a great cheer but in the silence that follows we hear the military band from across the way as the troops prepare to march off. Gandhi looks around at the crowd. Finally he speaks out. He makes the pranam and starts for the steps. The crowd is a little disappointed but they manage a cheer and applause. Nehru is standing next to a heavyset welldressed man. Patel. Nehru has slammed the door of a gleaming Rolls Royce touring car the top down. He has seated Gandhi in it beside. Patel taking Gandhi's knapsack. An Indian chauffeur rides in front. The crowd still surges around and Gandhi is looking apprehensively back for Ba. He grins boyishly in part to comfort in part unable to contain his amusement at Gandhi and his evident confusion. With Gandhi still looking back anxiously the car pulls off. He finally turns to Patel. There are crowds along the street and Gandhi  in surprise that they are for him  waves tentatively. Patel waves too but he eyes Gandhi rather critically.

test_cases.name: Complete Corruption
test_cases.description: The film starts with a man waking up in a small apartment. He prepares coffee and checks his phone for messages. There are none, so he heads out to catch a bus. On the way, he passes a neighbor who greets him briefly. At the bus stop, he notices a group of students talking about an upcoming test. He boards the bus and sits near the back, watching the city pass by outside the window. After a few stops, he gets off near a large office building. He enters the lobby and goes through security. He rides an elevator to the tenth floor, where he works as an assistant. His manager asks him to prepare some documents for a meeting later in the day. He collects files from different departments and organizes them in a conference room. Another employee asks him for help with a software issue, so he takes a few minutes to fix it. Then he returns to the conference room to double-check everything before the meeting begins. The meeting starts at noon. Several people join via video call, and others sit around the table. The manager outlines the project goals, and each team member shares updates on their tasks. There are questions about deadlines and budgets, but no big surprises. After an hour, they end the call. The manager thanks everyone and leaves. The assistant cleans up the room, collects leftover notes, and heads back to his desk. During lunch, he walks to a nearby café, where he orders a simple meal. He eats alone and checks social media on his phone. After lunch, he returns to the office and finishes smaller tasks, such as sending emails and filing paperwork. He also helps a coworker carry boxes of supplies to another floor. Later in the afternoon, the manager calls him in to discuss next week's schedule. They go over a few changes, and the assistant updates the calendar. When the workday ends, he logs off his computer and leaves the building. Outside, he walks a few blocks to meet a friend. They chat about weekend plans and decide to see a film on Saturday. The assistant then heads home on a crowded bus. At his apartment, he sorts his mail, feeds a pet cat, and warms up leftovers for dinner. He watches a short news segment on TV, then checks his phone again. A message from his friend confirms their plan for the weekend. He feels relieved to have something to look forward to. The film ends with him preparing for bed, setting an alarm, and turning off the lights. He reflects briefly on the day, thinking about his tasks, his quiet home, and the plans ahead.

test_cases.name: Summarization
test_cases.description: The commanding officer and Guard of Honor wait as the General takes the salute and inspects the troops, accompanied by a military band. A young Englishman observes this while noticing a well-dressed Indian nearby, who nods and moves away. Third Class passengers disembark from another gangplank, drawing excitement from a crowd of Indians reacting to someone unseen. Gandhi smiles, overwhelmed by the reception, as he answers an Indian journalist's questions. An English journalist approaches him, and a woman places a garland around his shoulders. Nehru, amused by the excitement, guides Gandhi through the crowd to a flower-covered platform with a CONGRESS PARTY banner. Gandhi, embarrassed, mounts the platform amid cheers, and after a brief speech, the crowd applauds. Nehru, with a well-dressed man (Patel), helps Gandhi into a Rolls Royce. Gandhi looks back for Ba, grinning to comfort her while the car pulls away. As they pass cheering crowds, Gandhi waves tentatively, while Patel observes him critically.
